texts.value: Essential for the degradation of glycogen in lysosomes (PubMed:1856189, PubMed:7717400, PubMed:14695532, PubMed:18429042). Has highest activity on alpha-1,4-linked glycosidic linkages, but can also hydrolyze alpha-1,6-linked glucans (PubMed:29061980)

reaction.name: Hydrolysis of terminal, non-reducing (1->4)-linked alpha-D-glucose residues with release of alpha-D-glucose.

texts.value: The different forms of acid glucosidase are obtained by proteolytic processing
Phosphorylation of mannose residues ensures efficient transport of the enzyme to the lysosomes via the mannose 6-phosphate receptor
There are three common alleles of GAA: GAA*1, GAA*2 and GAA*4. The sequence shown is that of allele GAA*1, which is the most common. Alleles GAA*2 and GAA*4 are much rarer

disease.description: A metabolic disorder with a broad clinical spectrum. The severe infantile form, or Pompe disease, presents at birth with massive accumulation of glycogen in muscle, heart and liver. Cardiomyopathy and muscular hypotonia are the cardinal features of this form whose life expectancy is less than two years. The juvenile and adult forms present as limb-girdle muscular dystrophy beginning in the lower limbs. Final outcome depends on respiratory muscle failure. Patients with the adult form can be free of clinical symptoms for most of their life but finally develop a slowly progressive myopathy.

texts.value: The disease is caused by variants affecting the gene represented in this entry
Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 31 family
